Speaker: Mr HOLT
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: Higgins-Minister for Labour and National Service and Minister for Immigration) [12.31 a.m.] - I That the bill be now read a second time. On the 16th March, 1949, the then Acting Attorney-General in the former Government made the following statement in I desire to inform honourable senators that it has been decided to prepare a consolidation of Commonwealth acts as at the 31st December, 1950. The consolidation will be published as early as possible in the year 1951. The first consolidation of Commonwealth acts was prepared as at the end of 1911, and a second as at the end of 1935. It was then intended to issue a fresh consolidation at the end of ten years, but that intention was, of course, frustrated by the war. It has also been decided to issue a consolidation of Commonwealth statutory rules as at the 31st December, 1950. The statutory rules have previously been reprinted twice, namely in 1.914 and 1927. Besides being of great utility, those works will mark the completion of 50 years of federation, and will - be issued to commemorate this important milestone in the history of the Commonwealth of Australia. The present Government has adopted the decision of the previous Government and the work of preparing Commonwealth acts for reprinting has been proceeding for some time. The Attorney General (Senator Spicer) has made a detailed statement in another place of the reasons for this bill. As he gave a good deal of detailed information concerning it, I do not consider that at this stage of the session it is necessary for me to go into the provisions of the bill in any detail, unless the House wish me to do so. The purpose of the bill is clear and I believe that honourable members on both sides of the House will agree that it is necessary. I therefore commend it to the House for speedy consideration.

Speaker: Dr EVATT
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: Barton-Deputy Leader of the Opposition) [12.32 a.m.] - The Opposition will support the hill. Indeed, its foundations were laid early in 1949 during the term of office of the Chifley Oovernment. Its object is that we shall have a Commonwealth statute-book that shall start afresh from the end of this year. It will get rid of a lot of dead wood in the statute-book. It will repeal many acts that have ceased to operate but which still cumber the statute-book. It will also alter titles of acts where such alterations are likely to clarify the scope of those acts and to clear up doubts. The whole point about the measure is that it will effect no alteration of the law, but will merely bring the law into a more convenient form. The bill is correctly titled the Statute Law Bevision Bill. Its result will be something like that which was achieved in 1935 by Sir George Knowles, who was then Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth. The new Commonwealth statute-book will start afresh as from the fiftieth anniversary of federation. That was the objective that we had in mind when we laid the foundations of the measure in 1949, and this Government is giving effect to it. We whole-heartedly support the bill. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. In committee: Clauses 1 to 6 agreed to. Clause 7- (1.) Section three of the Oustoms Tariff 1933-1049, as amended by the Oustoms Tariff 1950, is amended by omitting the definitions of " t a r if l ' alteration" and "the T a r (2.) Sections seven, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen and sixteen of the Customs Tariff 1933-1949, as amended by the Oustoms Tariff 1950, are repealed. (3.) The Customs Tariff 1933-1949. as amended by the Customs Tariff 1950, is amended by omitting from the items, or portions of items, in the Schedule to that Act as so amended which are specified in the first column of the F if t h Schedule to this Act the words respectively set out in the second column of the F if t h Schedule to this Act opposite to those items or portions of items. (4.) Section one of the Oustoms Tariff 1950 is amended by omitting sub-section (3.) . (5.) The Customs Tariff 1933-1949, as amended by the Customs Tariff 1950 and by this section, may be cited as the Customs Tariff 1933-1950.

Speaker: Mr HOLT
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: Higgins-Minister for Labour and National Service and Minister for Immigration) [12.35 a.m.] - I have circulated amendments that are purely formal and are consequential on other legislation that has been passed in the course of this session, and even in the last few days. I can give to the House the assurance mentioned by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Evatt) that the bill is not intended to make any alteration of the substance of the law. It will correct overlapping provisions which occur in more than one act, and will also correct verbal mistakes and delete words that are obviously unnecessary. The bill seeks to amend about 85 acts and to repeal just under 500 other acts. The amendments merely bring our legal story up to date, as it were, and I suggest that they might be adopted in their entirety. I move the following amendments to this clauseThat, in sub-clause (1.), after the words " Customs Tariff 1950 ", the following words be inserted:-"by the Customs Tariff (No. 2) 1950 and by the Customs Tariff {No. 3) 1950 ". That, in sub-clause (2.), after the words '* Customs Tariff 1950", the following words be inserted:-"by the Customs Tariff {No. 2) 1950 and by the Customs Tariff {No. 3) 1950 ". Tliat, in sub-clause (3.), after the words "Customs Tariff 1950", the following words be inserted:-"by the Customs Tariff (No. 2) 1950 and by the Customs Tariff (No. 3) 1950 ". That sub-clause (4.) be left out, with a view to insert in lieu thereof the following subclause :" (4.) Section one of the Customs T a r if j (No. 3) 1950 is amended by omitting subsection (4.)." That, in sub-clause (5.), after the words " Customs Tariff 1 9 5 0 the following words if f " . be inserted:-" , by the Oustoms Tariff (No. 2) 1950, by the Customs Tariff (No. 3) 1950".

Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: the Treasurer, upon notice I . What amount has been subscribed by private financial institutions to the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, under the provisions of the Bretton Woods - Agreement? 1.134] KalgoorUe to Port Augusta Railway Act 19111950 ". Land Tax Assessment Act 1910-1950 " . Offices) Adjustment Act 2. Is it a fact that, under the articles of the Bretton Woods Agreement, world private nnanciai and banking interests can and are attempting to dominate the Federal Government interests? 3. What proportion of the dollar loan recently negotiated in the United States of America by the Federal Government came under the provisions of the Bretton Woods Agreement ? PAPERS. 4. Will the Government secure from Prowere pre- fessor Melville, at the earliest opportunity, a report of his views concerning the working of the International Fund and International Bank in relation to the effect upon the overseas trade and the internal economy of Australia? 5. Will the Government inform the House, before, it rises, whether a delegation is about to visit Australia from the International Bank. If such a visit is proposed, when will the delegation arrive and what is the purpose of the visit?

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:1. Both the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development are international institutions exclusively representative of member Governments. Private financial institutions cannot subscribe to them or participate in their control. 2. No. See also answer to No. 1. 3. The whole of the recently negotiated 100,000,000 dollar loan is to be obtained from the International Bank for Beconstruction and Development. 4. Mr Melville was recently elected as an executive director of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and has taken up his duties in Washington. The Government will be receiving regular reports from him on the activities of the fund and the bank as they affect Australia. 5. No definite date has yet been fixed for a visit to Australia by oflicials of the In t e r national Bank. However I explained in my second-reading speech on the Loan (International Bank and Reconstruction and Development) Bill 1950, the president of the bank has offered, if the Government so desires, to send officials of the bank to Australia to gain a closer knowledge of our developmental programmes and to consider with us to whnt extent further participation by the Bank in the financing of these programmes may, in all the circumstances be necessary and justified. This oner has been welcomed by the Government and it is expected that a visit to Australia by officials of the Bank will be arranged early next year. MOTOR VEHICLES.

Speaker: Mr MCBRIDE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the 31st October, the honourable member for Mackellar (MT . Wentworth) askeci the following questions :1. How many Buick and Cadillac cars, complete with bodies, were imported under special licence from the 1st January, 1945, to the 30th June, 1950? 2. Will the Minister fpr Trade and Customs make available a complete list showing the date on which each permit was granted, the date of importation, the identification particulars of each car, the name of the person to whom the permit was granted, the reason for granting it , and details of any undertaking that was given in connection with the transaction, as woll as the name of any agent who acted for t'..u importer? The Minister for Trade and Customs has now furnished the following reply:1. There are no records available of importations of complete Buick and Cadillac cars prior to the 1st January, 1948. Between the 1st January, 1948, and the 30th June, 1950, special licences were granted for the importation of ofi Buick and five Cadillac cars, complete with bodies. This includes cars imported by diplomatic and consular representatives. 2. It is not desirable to make available for public information particulars of this nature, having reference to the business of private citizens.

Speaker: Mr MCBRIDE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the 5 th December, the honourable member for Bowman (Mr. MCColm) asked the following questions :1. Will the Minister for Trade and Customs ascertain whether pressed steel from dollar sources is being used for the manufacture of baths in Australia ? 2. If steel imported from dollar areas is being used for the manufacture of baths, will the Minister inquire whether the expenditure of dollars for this purpose is justified? The Minister for Trade and Customs has furnished the following reply:1. Licences have been issued for the importation of a small tonnage of steel sheets from dollar sources for use in the manufacture of baths. Information before the department at the time the licences were issued indicated that the steel was suitable for the pressing of baths which were then in short supply. 2. Yes. NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT.

Speaker: Mr LESLIE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: the Minister for National Development, upon notice In connection wit h the schedule recently supplied to honourable members setting out works of a developmental nature which are in an advanced stage of planning or are being undertaken by the Commonwealth and State governments, will he say(o) What direct financial contribution, if any, has been or will be made by the Commonwealth Government towards the preliminary and/or capital costs of the following works iri Western Australia:-(i ) South Fremantle steam power station; (i i ) South-west power scheme; (i i i ) increasing the output of coal from the Collie coal-fields; (iv ) the estimated cost of £1,100,000 and the work involved in the development of the Albany harbour; (v) the estimated cost of £1,000,000 and the work involved in the development of the Bunbury harbour; (vi) the estimated cost of £20,000,000 for extensions to the Fremantle harbour and the general improvements and additions' to wharf space; (v i i ) the survey and construction of the new 4-ft. 8^-in. gauge railway line between Perth and Kalgoorlie to join with the transcontinental raihvay, and (viii) the improvement and maintenance of natural forests and the development of exotic plantations in Western Australia; and (6) What direct assistance, other than financial has the Commonwealth Government rendered, or arranged to render, in connection with the above-mentioned works.

Speaker: Mr CASEY
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as f o l l o w s : (a) Of the projects listed by the honourable member the Commonwealth has directly incurred expenditure as follows:-(i-vi ) N i l ; (vii) the survey of a new standard gauge railSTEEL. way line between Perth and Kalgoorlie. £38,6G8; (viii) on Forestry-approximatel y £1,000 for equipment at a new forestry research station. Whether contributions will be made in the future is a matter of Government policy, which it is not the practice to discuss in reply to parliamentary questions. (b) Details of direct assistance, other than financial which has been rendered or is being considered, are as follows:-(iii ) Collie coalin the Collie coal-field area the Bureau of Mineral Resources has carried out geophysical surveys. These have determined the configuration and depth of the basin, and the results have assisted the West Australian Government in the planning of its drilling campaign; (v i i ) Bailway from Perth to Kalgoorlie-ther e have been negotiations since 1945 between the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments regarding Western Australian railways including the proposed line from Perth to Kalgoorlie. As I have already mentioned the Commonwealth contributed £38,608 towards the survey of this line. This survey has been held up by the Western Australian Government, but is sufficiently advanced to allow construction t« commence at any time. In March, 1949, a joint committee of Commonwealth and State officers submitted a report on the problem of the rehabilitation of Western Australian railways. Recently, the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments liave been considering this report. (viii ) Forestry-in January this year the Commonwealth cooperated with the Western Australian Government in the establishment of a forestry research station ,at Dwellingup. This station, which will conduct research into hardwood forests is at present staffed by State officers, the Commonwealth hopes to appoint staff shortly. In addition to this, the Commonwealth has assisted in an aerial survey for some 170,000 acres of forest. No direct assistance has been provided by the Commonwealth to the other projects mentioned. SOCIAL SERVICES. M.r. E. JAMES HABRISON asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Services, upon notice I. Is Lidcombe State Hospital an approved benevolent asylum for the purposes of section IS of the Social Services Consolidated Act? 2. Is the same hospital now equipped for the admission of patients transferred from ordinary hospitals; if so, will consideration be extended to the question of now classifying Lidcombe State Hospital as an ordinary hospital ? 3. Were the aged pensioners of Lidcombe Hospital paying 27s. 6d. a week for maintenance prior to the 2nd November, 1950, leaving only 15s. a week for personal needs? 4. Are the same inmates now required to pay a further 5s. a week for maintenance leaving then only 2s. 6d. a week out of the recent pension increases? 5. Will he take steps to give the full 7s. 6d. a week increase in this instance without delay ? fi. Do pensioners admitted to ordinary hospitals receive their pensions without deductions ?

Speaker: Sir EARLE PAGE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: The Social Services has supplied the following information:1. Yes, this institution, the f u ll title of is Lidcombe State Hospital and Home, is an approved benevolent asylum for the purposes of section 18 of the Social Services Consolidation Act. 2. Lidcombe State Hospital and Home does. admit aged, infirm and sick persons as hospital cases for temporary treatment. Its main function, however, is to accommodate, for an indefinite period, aged, infirm and sick persons who are i i i need of care, attention and treatment. As this function is the same as that of other benevolent asylums, it is not proposed to regard this Institution as an ordinary hospital. 3. Prior to the recent amendment, which operates from the 2nd November, 1950, pensioner-inmates of Lidcombe State Hospital and Home, aa well as those of other approved benevolent asylums were paid pensions at the institutional rate of 15s. a week specified in section 50 of the Social Services Consolidation Act and, in accordance with that section, the balance of the pension (then 27s. 6d. a week) was paid to the institution for the maintenance of the pensioner. 4. Under the Social Services Consolidation Amending Aet (No. 2) 1950 the maximum rate of age and invalid pensions was increased by 7s. Gd. from 42s. 6d. to 50s. a week, with effect from the 2nd November, 1950, and the pensions payable to inmates of benevolent asylums were increased by 2s. 6d. from 15s. to 17s. 6d. a week. Thus, under section 50 of the act, the amount payable to the institution for the maintenance of a pensioner wae increased by 5s. from 27s. 6d. to 32s. Gd. a week, commencing from the 2nd November, 1950. The average cost of maintaining an inmate in all approved benevolent asylums exceeds, and in some cases is much higher than, the 32s. 6d. a week now payable by the Commonwealth. The average cost of maintaining each inmate of the Lidcombe State Hospital and Home for the year ended the 30th June. 1949 was £3 5s. 9d. a week. 5. As Parliament has sanctioned the allocation of the increase of 7s. Od. where the pensioner is an inmate of an approved benevolent asylum, in the proportion of 2s. 6d. to the pensioner and 5s. to the institution, the Government does not propose to take any further action in the matter. This allocation preserves the percentage that the inmate's pension bears to the full pension, which has stood at approximately 35 per cent, for the past eight years. 6. Yes. ROYAL AUSTRALIAN NAVY.

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: the Minister for the Navy, upon notice I. Is it a fact that a certain sum of money is being held by the Commonwealth GovernMinister for ment as prize money for distribution to personnel of the naval service? 2. If so, will he indicate (a) what is the total amount of this fund, (b) when will this which prize money be distributed, and (o) what will be the method of distribution and what will be the approximate amount to be received by each member of the Naval Service entitled to receive same?

Speaker: Mr FRANCIS
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:1. Yes. 2. (a) £249,000 approximately. (b) An exact date cannot yet be given but the money will be distributed as soon as all details in connection therewith can be completed, (c) All eligible personnel will be requested to apply and nominate a bank account to which the amount w i ll be paid. The amount available for each person will be approximately £8. TOBACCO AND CIGABBTTES.

Speaker: Mr MOBBIDE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the 5th December the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gilmore) asked the following questions:1. Will the Minister for Trade and Customs state whether newspaper reports that the Government intends to increase the allocation of dollars for the purchase of American tohacco leaf are correct? 2. If the reports are correct, how many dollars will be allocated and for what type of leaf? The Minister for Trade and Customs has furnished the following reply:1. The newspaper reports are not correct. 2. The Government has not yet considered the question of the amount of dollars which will be made available for the purchase of tobacco leaf in the next licensing year which commences on the 1st A p r i l , 1951.

Speaker: Mr MCBRIDE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the 29th November the honourable memher for Parkes (Mr Haylen) asked the following questions:1. Would the Minister for Trade and Customs ascertain why it is that although Australia and Britain are not large growers of tobacco and must import considerable quantities, there is in this country a plentiful supply of imported English cigarettes of all kinds and a shortage of locally-manufactured cigarettes ? 2. Is it a fact that the English cigarettes are from sixpence to one shilling a packet dearer than local cigarettes? 3. Is the Minister aware of a report to the effect that as Christmas approaches Australian cigarettes are becoming scarcer? 4. Is it also a fact that the brands of cigarettes imported into this country from England are not known as even popular brands in Great Britain and that they were formerly sold to kaffirs in Africa and coolies in India? The Minister for Trade and Customs has furnished the following reply:1. The present demand for tobacco and cigarettes is estimated to be about 50 per cent, greater than in 1939. Australian manufacturers are not able to meet the full demand because it is not possible to provide all the dollars necessary to purchase the additional American leaf required. If sufficient dollars were made available to purchase all the leaf necessary to meet the full demand some items of essential raw material and capital equipment would be excluded from the dollar budget or the quantities now being purchased would be curtailed. The pTesent distribution of manufactured tobacco and cigarettes represents about 117 per cent, of the pre-war demand and to achieve this rate it is necessary to allocate to American leaf slightly more than 9 per cent, of the total of the ordinary dollar budget. The United Kingdom receives a substantial proportion of its requirements of American tobacco leaf under Marshall A i d and has contracted to take up the major portion of the Southern Bhodesian crop. The United Kingdom regards tobacco as the raw material for an export trade of long standing wihich is valuable in earning credits for the purchase of its food and otlier essential needs. 2. Yes, but the same cigarettes are dearer in the United Kingdom than they are in Australia. 3. Every year in the period immediately preceding Christmas large quantities of cigarettes packed in cartons containing 100 or 200 are used for gifts in trade circles and to private individuals and this makes it difficult for the normal purchaser of a single packet. Overall the distribution is greater at Christmas than any other period of the year. 4. It is not known whether these cigarettes are of a type formerly sold to kaffirs and coolies but as they find a ready sale in Australia it would appear that the quality cannot be entirely unsatisfactory. MUNITIONS ESTABLISHMENTS.

Speaker: Mr BEALE
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the Sth December, the honourable member for Hoddle (Mr. Cremean) asked the following questions :1. Will the Minister for Supply say whether the cadet engineer scheme is still in operation in relation to the entry to or promotion within the munitions establishment controlled by the Department of Supply? 2. If so, what are the present qualifications of entry into the scheme? 3. Who are the members of the selection committee and what sections of the department does each selector represent? 4. How many qualified candidates have presented themselves for selection from 1943 to the present time? 5. Ho.w many of such qualified candidates have been successful during the same period, and what are their names? I now advise the honourable member as follows:1. Yes. 2. Cadets are recruited by two methods: (a) Ifrom university or technical school students or apprentices in departmental factories who comply with the following requirements:(i) Applicant must be under 24 years of age at date of appointment except in case of ex-servicemen, who are eligible up to age of 31 years; (i i ) applicant must have at date of appointment completed at least the first year of an engineering course at an Australian university; or (i i i ) possess an engineering diploma from a recognized technical school and be eligible to matriculate and enter upon a course of engineering at an Australian university; (iv ) have passed at date of appointment sufficient subjects at a recognized technical college to qualify him to proceed wit h the third year of the course leading to the fellowship diploma in chemical engineering .at' the Melbourno Technical College; or (v) be an apprentice under 24 years 'of age at the time of appointment with not less than two years' service in a government factory who has qualified by_ matriculation for entry to the facility of engineering at an Australian university. (6) Under Publio Service Board general scheme for selection of cadets for various professional positions. Applicants in this category must he qualified by examination for entry into an Australian university to Che appropriate course of engineering. Under category (1) above selection-is arranged by the Public Service Board. 3. Mr E. J. W. Herbert, manager, Ordnance Pactory, Bendigo, Victoria; Jfr. W. A. Bedding, assistant manager. Explosives Factory, Maribyrnong; Colonel W. P. E. Schraeder, Superintendent of Design, Army Branch, Department of Supply; Mr J. HoIIingsworth, personnel manager, Government Aircraft Factories. The committee interviews eligible applicants in nil States of the Commonwealth and functions under the chairmanship of the local Public Service Inspector. 4. One hundred and one applicants were received in 1949; 181 applications were received in 1050. Supply of figures for.previous years will necessitate some research and will be supplied as soon aa possible. 5. Fifty-nine. There was no recruitment in 1045-41!. Namesma - H . E. Mill, H. I . W. L. O'Brien, L. J. Lutze, K. Q. Elthan, M. C. Morrison, L. W. Fleming, L. J. Wrigley, J. F. Rodoni, C. L. Cookson, J. R. Pascoe, 8. G. Schleiger. 1948 - B . B. MCClean, R. C. Tansell, K. Adlan, B. MBTTZIES - On the 27th September last, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Johnson) asked me the following question:I should like to know whether the Prime Minister can. give, at this stage, any indication of when real, and practical assistance to the gold-mining industry, as was promised by' him in his poliey speech last December, will be granted T I draw the attention of the honourable member to assistance which has been given to the gold-mining industry in connection with the procurement of machinery and diamond drillin g equipment. The Department of National Development is also undertaking, in association with State mining authorities, a comprehensive programme of geological, geophysical and gee-chemical surveys. These surveys have made and will continue to make a valuable contribution to mining exploration and will cover many parts of Australia including large areas in the goldfields of Western Australia. In fact, one of the first areas to be surveyed by the Bureau of Mineral Resources with an airborne magnetometer, which is being installed in an aircraft specially acquired for the purpose, w i l i be in the Western Australian goldfields. DOLXAB DEFICITS .

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the 9th November, the honourable member for West Sydney (Mr Minogue), asked me the followhig .question Will the Treasurer inform me what Australia's net dollar deficit was for the financial year that ended on the 30th June, last! I now supply the following information to the honourable member:Reasonably accurate estimates of Australia's balance of payments with individual countries G. or monetary areas are more difficult to obtain than estimates of Australia's balance of pay* ments with the rest of the world, The nest available estimate, however, of Australia's dollar balance of payments in 1949-50 shows a net deficit of 47,000,000 dollars. The major elements were as follows:APKBOXTMATB BALANCE or PAYMENTS WITH THE DOLLAR ABBA-1949-50 . US Sonars million. Merchandise exports f.o.b. .. 145 Merchandise imports f.o.b. .. 174 Adverse balance-merchandis e SI GOLD. Invisibles, net . - 5 Repayment of debt ' 11 Total adverse balance .. 47 Repayment of 11,000,000 dollars of debt arose from the maturity in New York of two semi governmental dollar loans amounting to 9,100,000 dollars and from normal sinking fund payments. The net debit of 5,000,000 dollars for invisibles is after niaking allowances for the inflow of dollar capital into Australia. Statistical inquiries on capital movements conducted by the Commonwealth Statistician in recent years have not yet been completed for 1049-50, and in any event it is impossible fbr these inquiries to cover all types of capital movement. The evidence available,, however, suggests that private capital arrived from the dollar area in substantial amounts during the year and that the inflow may have approached 70,000,000 dollars. Fart of this private capital inflow represented genuine dollar investment in Australia. It is clear, however, that a considerable part was of a speculative nature transferred in expectation of an alteration of the Australian exchange rate. Some of these funds may be used during the current financial yeaT to purchase Australian export commodities, thereby reducing Australia's dollar receipts from exports in the current year. Australia's gold production of about 30,000,000 dollars in 1049-50 was sold to the United Kingdom against payment in sterling. This gold may be regarded as equivalent to dollars and is thus an offset to the deficit for 1949-50 shown in the total. Australia's drawing of 20,000,000 dollars from the International Monetary Fund on the 24th October, 1949, was available to finance the deficit. After allowing for these sources of finance for the deficit and for an increase in Australia's dollar working balances by 4,000,000 dollars over the year, net purchases of dollars from the United Kingdom during 1949-50 amounted tn about 1,000,000 dollars. COMMONWEALTH BAHS . Mr CHABI.ES RUSSELL asked the Treasurer, upon notice I. Is the percentage of gross profit'to capital and reserves of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia for normal trading activities much 'lower than that for n trading bank in a comparative period. 2. If so, what is deemed' to be the reason or reasons underlying this state of affairs, and, particularly, is the accumulation of fuir.!:.' overseas having a derogatory affect on the Commonwealth Bank's profits by causing the London branch to show a loss on normal bank trading.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: The information requested by the honourable member is being obtained and will be furnished as soon as possible.

Speaker: Mr FADDEN
Title: STATUTE LAW REVISION
text: On the 29th November the. honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Beazley) asked a question in the following terms:In the absence of the Treasurer, I ask the Prime Minister a question relative to the custom of the Commonwealth Bank of insuring exporters, at a premium of 2s. 6d. per cent., against the possibility of loss resulting from re-valuation while their goods are in transit. If thu Government's decision against revaluation is definite and final will it issue an instruction to the Commonwealth Bank to desist from insuring against a certainty, or alternatively to reduce the rate of insurance! Will the Prime Minister be good enough to makv available to me details of the amount of money that the Commonwealth Bank has earned out of this insurance? I am advised by the Commonwealth Bank that it provides forward exchange facilities for exporters and importers bnt traders are free to determine whether or not they avail themselves of these facilities. Traders may, of course desire to insure against the risk of variations in exchange rates made overseas. The fee of approximately one per centum per annum charged for this service compares favourably with charges made for forward exchange cover in other countries. It may be regarded as in the nature of a small insurance premium and the bank does not consider any reduction is warranted. It is not the practice to publish the earnings arising from the various classes of business of a department of the bank and therefore it is not possible to furnish particulars of the bank's forward exchange earnings.
